fields.label: Primary Case type
fields.name: primary_case_type
fields.instructions: Which form will be used to edit this case?

sub_fields.label: Are you a public-sector employee involved with the innovation that you are submitting?
sub_fields.name: public_employee_involved

sub_fields.label: Do  you know the name and/or contact information for the public employee involved with the innovation?
sub_fields.name: public_official_involved

sub_fields.label: Notice!
sub_fields.message: To be published on the OPSI platform, each case study must have at least one public sector sponsor who is involved in the innovation project. You may still submit the innovation, but you would need to identify a public official prior to case study publication.

sub_fields.label: Invite collaborators
sub_fields.message: If your case study is accepted, you will have the opportunity to associate other collaborators who are members of the OPSI platform with the case study. You will be able to add or invite your collaborators via your profile page.

You can click on previously completed sections in the sidebar to navigate back to them in order if you wish to revise your entry. If you have any problems, please contact us at opsi@oecd.org (include a screenshot if possible).

sub_fields.label: Primary Sector
sub_fields.name: organisation_primary_sectorfield
sub_fields.instructions: What is your organisation's primary sector or field of activity

choices.environmental: Environmental protection, climate change, and agriculture
choices.public_order: Public order and safety, justice, and human rights

sub_fields.label: Summary Instructions
sub_fields.message: Now, we're going to ask you several questions about your innovation. We are very excited to find out what you did, how you did it and who benefited from it. Items marked with * are required before you submit your final draft. However, if you need to, you may skip them for now and return to them later from the link in your user profile. At the end of the submission process, you will have the opportunity to upload supporting materials and pictures, as well as submit video URLs (e.g., YouTube). The OPSI team is excited to read about your innovation. The more comprehensive your answers are, the easier it will be for the reviewers and readers to appreciate the aims and achievements of your innovative project.

sub_fields.label: Year Your Innovation was Put Into Practice
sub_fields.name: year_innovation_launched

sub_fields.label: Short and Simple Explanation
sub_fields.name: short_and_simple_explanation
sub_fields.instructions:
This explanation should describe your innovation in three short and simple sentences. The explanation will be the first description people will see searching for innovations in the case study repository. They will use this description to decide if they would like to read more about your innovation. The explanation should:
  • use clear and succinct language
  • compel the reader to continue reading about the innovation
  • be able to be understood by someone who knows nothing about the sector or the innovation
  • set the context for other professionals who are reading the case study
  • use simple, not sector-specific terminology (no idioms, slang, or domain-specific "buzz" words)
The explanation should describe:
  • why the innovation was developed or the problem/opportunity being addressed
  • what the innovation is and who it benefitted
  • why it is innovative

Click here for examples of a Short Explanation

sub_fields.label: Would you like to receive peer feedback on your explanation?
sub_fields.name: receive_feedback
sub_fields.instructions: If you select yes, other innovators will be shown your explanation and give you feedback about how easy it is to understand.

sub_fields.label: Innovation Overview
sub_fields.name: executive_summary
sub_fields.instructions:
The Innovation Overview is an overview of the project and outcomes. If you've already written a report about your project, this could also be your abstract or one-pager. This should summarize all of the information for the innovation at a high level. You will have the opportunity to elaborate on some of the details later in the submission. In approximately 3-4 paragraphs (maximum 5,000 characters), please tell us:
  • What problem the innovation solves or what opportunity was taken advantage of
  • What the innovation is
  • Objectives or goals of the innovation
  • Who benefited from the innovation
  • How is the innovation envisioned for the future? For example, how will it be institutionalised in its current context? How will it scale even bigger?
If applicable, you may also wish to include:
  • How a course of action was determined
  • Methods or tools used to implement the project
  • A description of another innovation you were inspired by

Click here for example of an Innovation Overview

sub_fields.label: Innovation Tags
sub_fields.name: innovation_tags
sub_fields.instructions:
Select at least 3 tags that describe your innovation. We encourage you to add additional tags as needed. These tags can describe the:
  • Innovation idea and type
  • Development process
  • Beneficiary
  • Other relevant aspects

sub_fields.label: Innovation Tags (OpenGov)
sub_fields.name: innovation_tags_opengov
sub_fields.instructions:
Select at least 3 tags that describe your innovation. We encourage you to add additional tags as needed. These tags can describe the:
  • Innovation idea and type
  • Development process
  • Beneficiary
  • Other relevant aspects

sub_fields.label: Custom Innovation Tags
sub_fields.name: custom_innovation_tags
sub_fields.instructions: You may add custom innovation tags by comma separating them, for example personalized information,data administration

sub_fields.label: Is this case part of the Open Government Partnership action plan in your country?
sub_fields.name: is_this_case_part_of_open_government_partnership_action_plan_in_your_country?

sub_fields.label: What Makes Your Project Innovative?
sub_fields.name: what_makes_your_project_innovative
sub_fields.instructions:
We're eager to hear about how your project is innovative. In approximately 1-2 paragraphs (maximum 1,000 characters), tell us how your innovation is:
  • Different, unique or more innovative than the what's been tried previously in your organisation, other organisations, or other countries

Click here for example of a "What Makes Your Project Innovative?"

sub_fields.label: Innovation Status
sub_fields.name: innovation_status
sub_fields.instructions:
First choose the current status of your innovation.
Then in 1-2 paragraphs, describe what is happening with your project right now (maximum 1,000 characters). Check all that apply and feel free to elaborate below if you feel the innovations phases below do not accurately describe your innovation's current status.

choices.identifying_problems: Identifying or Discovering Problems or Opportunities - learning where and how an innovative response is needed
choices.generating_ideas: Generating Ideas or Designing Solutions - finding and filtering ideas to respond to the problem or opportunity
choices.developing_proposals: Developing Proposals - turning ideas into business cases that can be assessed and acted on
choices.evaluation: Evaluation - understanding whether the innovative initiative has delivered what was needed
choices.diffusing: Diffusing Lessons - using what was learnt to inform other projects and understanding how the innovation can be applied in other ways

sub_fields.label: Innovation Status Text
sub_fields.name: status_description
sub_fields.instructions: Click here for example of a Status Description

sub_fields.label: Collaborations & Partnerships
sub_fields.name: collaboration_partnerships
sub_fields.instructions:
What Collaborators or Partners were involved in the innovation process? Describe what each brought to the table and why it was important to the innovation (maximum 500 characters). These may include:
  • Citizens
  • Government officials
  • Civil society organisations
  • Companies

Click here for example for Collaboration & Partnerships

sub_fields.label: Users, Stakeholders & Beneficiaries
sub_fields.name: users_stakeholders_beneficiaries
sub_fields.instructions:
Describe each of the users, stakeholder and/or beneficiaries for the innovation and how each group was affected (maximum 500 characters). These may also include:
  • Citizens
  • Government officials
  • Civil society organisations
  • Companies

Click here for example for Users, Stakeholders and Beneficiaries

sub_fields.label: Results, Outcomes & Impacts
sub_fields.name: results_impact
sub_fields.instructions:
Describe the results, outcomes and Impacts of the innovation (maximum 1,000 characters).
  • What results and impacts have been observed from the innovation so far?
  • How have the results and impacts been measured (e.g., methodologies used)?
  • What results and impacts do you expect in the future?
  • To the extent possible, please indicate the tangible or numeric results.

Click here for example Results, Outcomes & Impact

sub_fields.label: Challenges and Failures
sub_fields.name: challenges
sub_fields.instructions:
Describe what challenges have been faces, and potentially what failures have occurred (maximum 1,000 characters).
  • What challenges have been encountered?
  • What failures have been encountered along the way (e.g., structural failures or significant setbacks)?
  • And how, if at all, have those challenges and/or failures been responded to?

Click here for example of Challenges

sub_fields.label: Conditions for Success
sub_fields.name: conditions_to_success
sub_fields.instructions:
What conditions do you think are necessary for the success of an innovation such as this (maximum 1,000 characters)? Conditions for success may include:
  • Supporting infrastructure and services
  • Policy and rules
  • Leadership and guidance
  • Human and financial resources
  • Personal values and motivation

Click here for example of Conditions for Success

sub_fields.label: Replication
sub_fields.name: potential_to_be_replicated
sub_fields.instructions:
Has the innovation been replicated to address similar problems? If so, how? In your opinion, what is the potential for the innovation to be further replicated in the future? (maximum 1,000 characters) You may wish to discuss how the innovation has already been used by others, as well as how you believe your innovation could be used by others in the future. These others may be in:
  • Other organisations
  • Within your organisation
  • Larger or smaller agencies, organisations or governments

Click here for example of Replication

sub_fields.label: Lessons Learned
sub_fields.name: lessons_to_share
sub_fields.instructions:
What lessons from your experience would you like to share with others like you (maximum 2,000 characters)?

Click here for example of Lessons Learned

sub_fields.label: Anything Else?
sub_fields.name: information_to_share
sub_fields.instructions: Is there any other information you would like to share about the innovation?

sub_fields.label: Materials
sub_fields.name: photo_and_video
sub_fields.instructions: Visual assets and supporting materials help to bring your innovation to life. Do you have other materials you'd like to include with your submission? Please use the fields below to upload images (in jpg and png format) and other relevant documents (in .pdf, .doc, .docx, .ppt., .pptx., .odt, .xls, .xlsx, .txt, .mp3, .m4a, .ogg, .wav). You may also submit a brief video project pitch and specify up to two additional videos (insert YouTube, Vimeo URLs).

sub_fields.label: 1-2 Minute Video Pitch
sub_fields.name: video_url_1
sub_fields.instructions: For additional consideration, you may record a one-two minute video pitch about your innovation, host it on YouTube or a similar video sharing platform, and link it here. Additional supporting videos may be linked below.

sub_fields.name: form_feedback
